body_content.explanation: used to refer in an approximate way to an object or to avoid naming it:
examples: What's that thing over there?
There are some nice things in the shops this summer.
I don't eat sweet things (= sweet food).
How does this stupid thing work?

body_content.explanation: your possessions or a particular set of your possessions:
examples: All their things were destroyed in the fire.
Bring your swimming things if the weather's nice.

body_content.explanation: a particular set of objects:
examples: Let me help you clear away the tea things (= cups, plates, etc. that are used for having tea).

body_content.explanation: used to refer in an approximate way to an idea, subject, event, action, etc.:
examples: That was an unkind thing to say.
I've got so many things to do I don't know where to start.
Your information is correct but you left out one thing.
"What's the matter?" "It's this insurance thing. I'm really worried about it."

body_content.explanation: the exact fact, object, idea, event, etc.:
examples: The article was exactly the thing I needed for my research.

body_content.explanation: something that is not false or a copy:
examples: The fire alarm goes off accidentally so often that when it's the real thing (= when it really does happen) nobody will take any notice.

body_content.explanation: the same:
examples: Training isn't the same thing as education.

body_content.explanation: everything that has been planned or discussed:
examples: Let's call the whole thing off.
I want to forget the whole thing.

body_content.explanation: more than everything else:
examples: I value my freedom above all things.

body_content.explanation: in every situation or subject; in everything:
examples: Be true to yourself in all things.

body_content.explanation: said before describing what it is that you especially want to know:
examples: If there's one thing I want to know, it's where he goes on Thursday afternoons.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to the general situation:
examples: Things have been going very well recently.

body_content.explanation: If it's a good thing that something happened, it is lucky that it happened:
examples: It's a good thing (that) we booked our tickets early.

body_content.explanation: in the present situation:
examples: The way things are, I'll never have this ready by June.

body_content.explanation: used instead of "anything" to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: Don't worry about a thing. I'll take care of it.

body_content.explanation: not anything:
examples: After the guests had gone, there wasn't a thing left to eat.

body_content.explanation: to have no clothes that are suitable for an occasion:
examples: I'm going to a wedding on Saturday and I don't have a thing to wear.

body_content.explanation: you cannot do anything:
examples: He broke his promise and there wasn't a thing we could do about it.

body_content.explanation: used to talk about a particular action, agreement, etc.:
examples: I went by plane, a thing I hardly ever do.
One thing you'll have to agree to is working in the evenings.

body_content.explanation: used to make noun phrases with particular adjectives and adverbs:
examples: The first thing (to do) is to write your name at the top of the paper.

body_content.explanation: used to introduce a reason for something:
examples: "Why won't you come to New York with me?" "For one thing, I don't like flying, and for another, I can't afford it."

body_content.explanation: used after an adjective to refer to a person or animal with love or sympathy:
examples: The poor things were kept in small cages without room to move.
I can't believe you won - you lucky thing!
